content.description:
A tough traverse across the Full Tilt boulders.  

  Start the same as for Full Tilt, and make the same first few moves, but instead of breaking up and left to top out on the boulder that forms the roof, continues heading right on the seam/crack. Traverse all the way across the boulder until you reach the right arete, finish up on that arete.
content.protection: Couple pads for the uneven landing of the first half of the problem. The traverse on the seam has a flat landing that doesn't need to be padded.
content.location: On the same boulder as Full Tilt. From the gazebo, look left and head into the woods a bit and you'll see a pancake shaped boulder lying on top of some other boulders forming a little roof.

content.description: Squat start matched on the jug in the horizontal split, and lunge direct to a good edge at the lip.
content.location: This line is to the left of Clever and Devoted, and right of Full Tilt.

content.description:
A super sweet traverse problem that uses multiple boulders and a crazy roof. Double kneebars, toe hooks, heel hooks, and crosses oh my! 

  Start matched on the bottom of the roof with a double kneebar and little rock for feet. Traverse your way around using the roof and the next two boulders to eventually top out on the roof. The big boulder to the left of the roof is not used. 

  It might be a good idea to brush holds of before you climb on them as it can get pretty dusty in this cave.  

  This video is really helpful for understanding this route since not many problems out there use multiple boulders.  

youtube.com/watch?v=usqlDI_â€¦
content.protection: 2 or 3 pads. A spotter would be nice for the topout.
content.location: From the gazebo, look left to the South End boulders. Find the pancake like boulder lying on top of some other boulders, that's where this is.

content.description: Start on the right side of the boulder in a squat-start with a hand on either side of the arete. Move out and hand traverse left along the lips with good holds, a couple of nice heels in the middle of the face. Then make  a big move and figure out how to pull around the left end and top out.
content.location: To the right of Dragon's Back and Full Tilt on the boulder that looks a bit like a mushroom.

content.description: Sit start with left hand on a knob on the arete, and the right hand on a low sloper with some divots and crystals. Find bad feet and pull on and hit the sloper shelf, or spin around and bat hang the sloper shelf to get off the ground. From the sloper shelf move left around the arete to a thin crack and good diagnol holds with difficulty. From these sidepulls climb straight up and top out.
content.protection: A slider pad for the sit start, or a full pad for the bat-hang start. May want a spotter for the top out.
content.location: This line is located on the boulder next to the Full Tilt Roof, on the right side.

content.description: Sit start as for Clever and Devoted, but once on the sloper shelf, bring right hand up to the diagnol slopey right arete, and left hand up the left arete. Compress your way up until you can lunge for the fin shaped lip, then topout.
content.location: To the right of the Full Tilt Roof. This climb is located fairly close to the gazebo, only a 2 minute walk from there into the woods on the left.

content.description: This is a cluster of three or four adjacent boulders which form some pretty unique features. This cluster offers a fun traverse following a seam and a Jake Perry original named "Full Tilt".
